posts.name: Preston Maness
posts.cooked:
Howdy folks. I have been utilizing Signal with Tor (an anonymizing overlay network) via Orbot for a couple years now. For chats, it has worked without any observable problems. I‚Äôd love to see Signal force its chat traffic (really, any TCP traffic) over the Tor network (or some other anonymizing overlay). This would significantly frustrate efforts to build up social graphs of Signal users via metadata, as the underlying messaging systems (FCM, APN) would no longer see Signal user‚Äôs IP addresses and instead see Tor network IP addresses.

If I were to start working on code to support this, would Signal ever consider making it default behaviour? Signal is in a unique position in the world, as it has built up a considerable network and reputation for privacy. Shutting off the metadata tap would be an excellent step forward in its mission.

link_counts.title: Why aren't Molly features being ported into Signal (yet)?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
This seems identical to:

Use the built-in Tor Project in the program source Feature Requests
Hi What do you think about the Tor Project entering the Signal source? As a layer of security for those who need more security and also bypassing Internet censorship in countries like Iran. Iran has blocked the signal and Tor works well in this country, especially with the bridges. By entering the Tor Project into the program, anyone who needs to activate it manually in Signal. Also in parts of the world where Signal access is blocked, the user can manually activate Tor within the Signal app. ‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: Use the built-in Tor Project in the program source

posts.name: Preston Maness
posts.cooked: That was the closest post I saw before making mine, but it was from 3 years ago (and it had no replies). I don‚Äôt know this forum‚Äôs policy on necrobumping, so I made a new post.

I‚Äòm really against this suggestion.
Tor always costs a lot of performance. Someone, who has a really, really fast internet connection might not feel the difference.
But if you‚Äòre often around in areas, with average connection, it might happen, that, for example, a Signal video call would be possible, and just using Tor basically decreases the quality of the call so much, that it becomes useless.

I‚Äòm pretty sure, this would convince more people to leave Signal, than bring new users.

If I can gain anything from this proposal, than you could force this traffic via Tor for text messages only. But I‚Äòm not really a fan of that either.

posts.name: Preston Maness
posts.cooked:
If I can gain anything from this proposal, than you could force this traffic via Tor for text messages only.

That is my idea, yes. As I understand it, voice and video happen with UDP (at least by default), which Tor doesn‚Äôt support anyway. And yes, voice and video calls over Tor have been a struggle for me. But text is the majority of my usage, and pushing it over Tor has worked for me at least.

Now, suddenly introducing several million new connections to the Tor network, even if only for lightweight text and data traffic, could conceivably overwhelm the network too. I don‚Äôt know just how much traffic Signal generates and how much the Tor network can handle. But that is a technical problem that can be solved by expanding the Tor network, something that would benefit all its users regardless of whether or not they use Signal specifically. And it‚Äôs something that sounds right up Signal‚Äôs alley too.
To hide IP addresses from their servers, Signal could use Oblivious HTTP via a third-party: Oblivious HTTP Relay
Is it possible for someone to set up a Signal proxy that connects over Tor, then set up a phone to connect through the proxy?

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
Hi @aspensmonster, welcome to the forum!
This feature request is very interesting. As was already pointed out there are technical challenges or disadvantages of using an anonymization network.
But another point I find is interesting is thinking about what privacy/security improvements you aim to achieve with the feature and if using Tor could give you that.

Let‚Äôs have a look on the messaging system part you mentioned. I think the vast majority of signal users uses Signal on a device that has FCM/APN installed (can only be removed with a custom ROM afaik) and also has a google account/ apple id connected with their device. My understanding is that through the FCM push token being associated with the google account ID google/apple always knows who a user of this service is and can target the person for e.g. traffic analysis. Using tor would only protect the IP (and therefore maybe the location) of the user, but would not make them anonymous.

The same goes for connecting to the Signal Servers via Tor. Signal does not see your IP, but already knows your phone number. So if you didn‚Äôt buy your SIM card anonymously (giving your state ID is required to buy a SIM in many countries), I think you won‚Äôt win much additional privacy/security.

A point one could probably make: Many API calls to the Signal Server are unauthenticated. But probably the Signal app also regularly makes authenticated (linkable to your account) connections from the same IP, so correlation would not be hard. If your traffic comes from a proxy that is also used by many other Signal users, this might get much harder. Of course that would be a scenario where you want to protect against active traffic correlation attacks by the Signal Server. Is this a thing you would hope to achieve or do you think more about other scenarios?

posts.name: Preston Maness
posts.cooked:
To hide IP addresses from their servers, Signal could use Oblivious HTTP via a third-party

That looks like an interesting half-way point, at least But its applicability section raises my main concerns:

Importantly, it requires explicit support from a willing Oblivious Relay Resource and Oblivious Gateway Resource, thereby limiting the use of Oblivious HTTP for generic applications; see Section 6.3 for more information.

‚Ä¶

Oblivious HTTP is simpler and less costly than more robust systems, like Prio ([PRIO]) or Tor ([DMS2004]), which can provide stronger guarantees at higher operational costs.

If we have to trust a willing relay and gateway, then we‚Äôre back to traffic analysis being an easy path for building up a social graph.

Is it possible for someone to set up a Signal proxy that connects over Tor, then set up a phone to connect through the proxy?

I am not sure. I haven‚Äôt had a chance to play with Signal‚Äôs proxy as of yet.

My understanding is that through the FCM push token being associated with the google account ID google/apple always knows who a user of this service is and can target the person for e.g. traffic analysis.

Indeed, Google will know that a particular user is using signal, which is a separate concern that I honestly don‚Äôt know how to meaningfully address. If you use Google‚Äôs service, well, their whole business is surveillance Perhaps adopting Unified Push could be an avenue for eventually shutting down that particular leak.

But my understanding is that the FCM/APM notifications have no other information in them, instead telling the Signal client to query the Signal servers for actual message content. Meaning, just monitoring Google‚Äôs FCM (or Apple‚Äôs APN) traffic, on its own, makes knowing who is talking to who difficult. It‚Äôs watching the traffic going to and from Signal‚Äôs servers that enables social graph build-up.

The same goes for connecting to the Signal Servers via Tor. Signal does not see your IP, but already knows your phone number. So if you didn‚Äôt buy your SIM card anonymously (giving your state ID is required to buy a SIM in many countries), I think you won‚Äôt win much additional privacy/security.

I won‚Äôt get into the ‚Äúphone numbers are a requirement‚Äù debate --suffice to say I believe that anonymous sign-ups to Signal‚Äôs network should be permitted for precisely the reason you raise-- but I do think that a Signal server that sees a bunch of Tor-originated traffic will be more difficult to effectively surveil than one where every user‚Äôs device is using plain IP addresses. Under that regime, surveillance is limited to whatever Sealed Sender envelopes they can scoop up for knowing ‚Äúa phone number received a message from‚Ä¶ someone.‚Äù Basically, under this regime, they‚Äôre back to only knowing what monitoring FCM/APN already tells them: ‚Äúthis person is using Signal.‚Äù Building up a social graph becomes much more difficult.

If your traffic comes from a proxy that is also used by many other Signal users, this might get much harder. Of course that would be a scenario where you want to protect against active traffic correlation attacks by the Signal Server. Is this a thing you would hope to achieve or do you think more about other scenarios?

That is exactly the idea. If Signal is having all its clients utilize the Tor network (at least for chat/data), then traffic correlation becomes more difficult and patchwork.

aspensmonster:

If we have to trust a willing relay and gateway, then we‚Äôre back to traffic analysis being an easy path for building up a social graph.

The relay and gateway would be operated by different parties. Namely Fastly would operate the relay and Signal would operate the target. Obviously there is still a chance of collusion but better than the status quo.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
(I haven‚Äôt read all the comments, just saying)
not to go against this feature request, but Molly has support for SOCKS and Tor proxies.
Disagree‚Ä¶ Its media up to 100mb and most of the time its just messaging? you wont feel any latency in just messages anyway‚Ä¶

Tor is also really good at censorship cricumvention.
Which Signal seems to be struggeling with, since AWS started fighting it.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: How good is it in countries like China and Russia?

Okay.
It works pretty well most of the time, but once in a while(4 years in a bad period most of the time it‚Äôs longer) they figure out how to block it and it doesn‚Äôt work for a month, before there is a patch.

Edit:
You can check the tor metrics page for a more comprehensive overview.
They call these moments ‚Äúcensorship events‚Äù.

Looked it up through that page I suggested.
Turns out those ‚Äúcensorship events‚Äù don‚Äôt block the whole service, but a few of their proxying tricks.
They call these trick bridges if you‚Äôre looking for inspiration.
